sp.l: Do but behold me
If there be pity in you, do but view me,
But view the misery I have undertaken
For you the poverty.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He will come presently.
Now play your best sir, though I lose this rook here
Yet I get liberty.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I'll seize your fair hand
And warm it with a hundred, hundred kisses
The god of love warm your desires but equal
That shall play my game now.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?
Why do you stop me?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: That ye may intend me.
The time has blessed us both: love bids us use it.
I am a gentleman nobly descended:
Young to invite your love, rich to maintain it.
I bring a whole heart to ye, thus I give it,
And to those burning altars thus I offer,
And thus divine lips, where perpetual spring grows.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Take that, ye are too saucy.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: How proud lady?
Strike my deserts?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I was too blame.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What wise, there?
Heaven keep my house from thieves.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I am wretched:
Opened, discovered, lost to my wishes.
I shall be whooted at.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What noise was this (Wife?)
Why dost thou smile?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: This proud thing will betray me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why these lie here? what anger (Dear?)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why none, sir,
Only a chance, your pupil said he played well,
And so indeed he does: he undertook for ye
Because I would not sit so long time idle
I made my liberty avoided your mate,
And he again as cunningly endangered me,
Indeed he put me strangely to it. When presently
Hearing you come, and having broke his ambush too
Having the second time brought off my Queen fair,
I rose o'th' sudden smilingly to show ye,
My apron caught the chessboard, and the men,
And there the noise was.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou art grown a master,
For all this, I shall beat ye.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Or I, lawyer,
For now I love her more, 'twas a neat answer,
And by it hangs a mighty hope, I thank her
She gave my pate a sound knock that it rings yet,
But you shall have a sounder if I live lawyer,
My heart aches yet I would not be in that fear —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am glad ye are a gamester, sir, sometimes
For recreation we two shall fight hard at it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He will prove too hard for me,

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I hope he shall do,
But your chessboard is too hard for my head, line that good lady,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have been atoning two most wrangling neighbours,
They had no money, therefore I made even
Come, let's go in, and eat, truly I am hungry.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I have eaten already, I must entreat your pardon

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do as ye please, we shall expect ye at supper.
He has got a little heart, now it seems handsomely,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You'll get no little head, if I do not look to ye.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: If ever I do catch thee again thou vanity —

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I was too blame to be so rash, I am sorry —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Hear but my reasons,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O my patience hear 'em.
Can cunning falsehood colour an excuse?
With any seeming shape of borrowed truth?
Extenuate this woeful wrong, not error.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: You gave consent that to defeat my brother
I should take any course,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But not to make
The cure more loathsome than the foul disease:
Was't not enough you took me to your bed,
Tired with loose dalliance, and with empty veins,
All those abilities spent before and wasted,
That could confer the name of mother on me?
But that (To perfect my account of sorrow)
For my long barrenness you must heighten it
By showing to my face, that you were fruitful
Huged in the base embraces of another?
If solitude that dwelled beneath my roof,
And want of children was a torment to me
What end of my vexation to behold
A bastard to upbraid me with my wants?
And hear the name of father paid to ye
Yet know myself no mother,
What can I say?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Shall I confess my fault and ask your pardon?
Will that content ye?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: If it could make void,
What is confirmed in court no, no, don Henrique
You shall know that I find myself abused,
And add to that I have a woman's anger,
And while I look upon this basilisk
Whose envious eyes hath blasted all my comforts
Rest confident I'll study my dark ends,
And not your pleasures,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Noble lady, hear me,
Not as my father's son, but as your servant,
Vouchsafe to hear me, for such in my duty,
I ever will appear: and far be it from
My poor ambition, ever to look on you,
But with that reverence; which a slave stands bound
To pay a worthy mistress: I have heard
That dames of highest place, nay Queens themselves,
Disdain not to be served by such as are
Of meanest birth: and I shall be most happy,
To be employed when you please to command me
Even in the coursest office, as your page,
I can wait on your trencher:: fill your wine
Carry your pontafles, and be sometimes blessed
In all humility to touch your feet
Or if that you esteem that too much grace
I can run by your coach: observe your looks
And hope to gain a fortune by my service,
With your good favour, which now, as a son,
I dare not challenge

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: As a son,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Forgive me
I will forget the name, let it be death
For me to call you mother.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Still upbraided?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No way left to appease you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: None: now hear me,
Hear what I vow before the face of heaven,
And if I break it all plagues in this life,
And those that after death are feared, fall on me,
While that this bastard stays under my roof,
Look for no peace at home, for I renounce
All offices of a wife,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What am I fallen to?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will not eat, nor sleep with you and those hours
Which I should spend in prayers for your health
Shall be employed in curses,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Terrible.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: All the day long, I'll be as tedious to you
As lingering fevers, and I'll watch the nights,
To ring aloud your shame and break your sleeps
Or if you do but slumber, I'll appear
In the shape of all my wrongs, and like a fury
Fright you to madness, and if all this fail
To work out my revenge, I have friends and kinsmen,
That will not sit down tame with the disgrace
That's offered to our noble family
In what I suffer,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: How am I divided
Between the duties I owe as a husband,
And piety of a parent?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I am taught sir
By the instinct of nature that obedience
Which bids me to prefer your peace of mind,
Before those pleasures that are dearest to me
Be wholly hers (My lord) I quit all parts,
That I may challenge: may you grow old together
And no distaste e'er find you and before
The characters of age are printed on you
May you see many images of yourselves,
Though I, like some false glass, that's never looked in
Am cast aside , and broken from this hour
(Unless invited, which I dare not hope for)
I never will set my forbidden feet,
Over your threshold: only give me leave
Though cast off to the world, to mention you,
In my devotions 'tis all I sue for
And so I take my last leave

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Though I am
Devoted to a wife nay almost soled
A slave to serve her pleasures, yet I cannot
So part with all humanity, but I must
Show something of a father: thou shalt not go
Unfurnished and unfriended too: take that
To guard thee from necessities; may thy goodness
Meet many favours, and thine innocence
Deserve to be the heir of greater fortunes,
Than thou were't born to. Scorn me not Violante
This banishment is a kind of civil death,
And now, as it were at his funeral
To shed a tear or two, is not unmanly
And so farewell for ever: one word more,
Though I must never see thee (My Ascanio)
When this is spent (For so the judge decreed)
Send to me for supply: are you pleased now?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yes: I have cause: to see you howl and blubber
At the parting of my torment, and your shameBed ready, wine, table Standish and paper.
'Tis well: proceed: supply his wants: do do:
Let the great dowry I brought serve to maintain
Your bastard's riots: send my clothes and jewels,
To your old acquaintance, your dear dame his mother
Now you begin to melt, I know 'twill follow,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Is all I do misconstrued?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will take
A course to right myself a speeding one:
By the blessed saints, I will; if I prove cruel
The shame to see thy foolish pity taught me
To lose my natural softness, keep off from me
Thy flatteries are infectious, and I'll flee thee
As I would do a leper.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Let not fury
Transport you so: you know I am your creature,
All love, but to yourself, with him, hath left me
I'll join with you in any thing

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In vain
I'll take mine own ways, and will have no partners,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will not cross you,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Do not, they shall find
That to a woman of her hopes beguiled
A viper trod on, or an aspic's, mild. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sits the game there? I have you by mine order,
I love Leandro for't

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But you must show it
In lending him your help, to gain him means
And opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He shall want nothing,
I know my advocate to a hair, and what
Will fetch him from his prayers, if he use any,
I am honeyed with the project: I would have him horned
For a most precious beast.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: But you lose time;

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am gone, instruct you Diego, you will find him
A sharp and subtle knave, give him but hints
And he will amplify: see all things ready
I'll fetch him with a vengeance. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: If he fail now,
We'll give him over too,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Tush he is fleshed,
And knows what vain to strike for his own credit.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: All things are ready.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then we shall have a merry scene, nor fear it.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Amaranta (With a note) and Moore.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Is thy master gone out?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Even now, the curate fetched him,
About a serious business as it seemed,
For he snatched up his cloak, and brushed his hat straight,
Set his band handsomely, and out he galloped.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis very well, he went out (Egla.)
As luckily, as one would say, go husband,
He was called by providence: fling this short paper
Into Leandro's cell, and waken him,
He is monstrous vexed, and musty, at my chess-play;
But this shall supple him, when he has read it:
Take your own recreation for two hours,
And hinder nothing.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: If I do, I'll hang for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If that you loved Ascanio for himself,
And not your private ends, you rather should
Bless the fair opportunity, that restores him
To his birthright, and the honours he was born to,
Then grieve at his good fortune.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Grieve Octavio?
I would resign my essence, that he were
As happy as my love could fashion him,
Though every blessing that should fall on him,
Might prove a curse to me, my sorrow springs
Out of my fear, and doubt he is not safe.
I am acquainted with don Henrique's nature,
And I have heard too much the fiery temper
Of madam Violante: can you think
That she, that almost is at war with heaven
For being barren, will with equal eyes
Behold a son of mine?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: His father's care,
That for the want of issue took him home,
(Though with the forfeiture of his own fame)
Will look unto his safety.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Stepmother's
Have many eyes, to find a way to mischief,
Though blind to goodness.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here comes don Jamy,
And with him our Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Jamy.
sp.l: Good youth leave me,
I know thou art forbidden my company,
And only to be seen with me, will call on
Thy father's anger.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Sir if that to serve you
Could lose me any thing (As indeed it cannot)
I still would follow you. Alas I was born
To do you hurt but not to help myself,
I was, for some particular end, took home,
But am cast off again.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: The lady, whom my father calls his wife
Abhors my sight, is sick of me, and forced him
To turn me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: By my best hopes
I thank her cruelty, for it comes near
A saving charity.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I am only happy
That yet I can relieve you, pray you share:
My father's wondrous kind, and promises
That I should be supplied: but sure the lady
Is a malicious woman, and I fear
Means me no good.

sp.speaker: Jamy.
sp.l: I am turned a stone with wonder,
And know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: From my lady,
Your private ear and this —

sp.speaker: Iamy.
sp.l: New miracles?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: She says, if you dare make yourself a fortune,
She will propose the means; my lord don Henrique
Is now from home and she alone expects you,
If you dare trust her so, if not despair of
A second offer,Exit.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Though there were an ambush
Laid for my life, ay, ll on and sound this secret,
Retire thee (My Ascanio) with thy mother:
But stir not forth, some great design's on foot,
Fall what can fall, if e'er the sun be set,
I see you not, give me dead.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: We will expect you,
And those blessed angels, that love goodness, guard you.

div.head: Scaena quinta.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is't possible he should be rich?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Most possible,
He hath been long, though he had but little gettings,
Drawing together, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Accounted a poor sexton,
Honest poor Diego,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I assure ye, a close fellow,
Both close, and scraping, and that fills the bags, sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A notable good fellow too?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sometimes, sir,Diego ready in bed, wine, cup.
When he hoped to drink a man into a surfeit,
That he might gain by his grave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So many thousands?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Heaven knows what.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis strange,
'Tis very strange; but we see by endeavour,
And honest labour —

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Milo by continuance
Grew from a silly calf (With your worship's reverence)
To carry a bull, from a penny, to a pound, sir,
And from a pound, to many: 'tis the progress.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye say true, but he loved to feed well also,
And that methinks —

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: From another man's trencher, sir,
And there he found it seasoned with small charge:
There he would play the tyrant, and would devour ye
More than the graves he made, at home he lived
Like a chameleon sucked th'air of misery,Table out standish paper, stools.
And grew fat by th'brews of an eggshell,
Would smell a cook's shop, and go home and surfeit,
And be a month in fasting out that fever.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: These are good symptoms: does he lie so sick say ye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O, very sick.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And chosen me executor?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Only your worship.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No hope of his amendment?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: None, that we find.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He hath no kinsmen neither?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: 'Truth, very few.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His mind will be the quieter,
What doctors has he?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: There's none sir he believes in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are but needless things, in such extremities.
Who draws the goodman's will?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Marry that do I, sir.
And to my grief.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Grief will do little now, sir,
Draw it to your comfort, friend, and as I counsel ye,
An honest man, but such men live not always
Who are about him?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Many now he is passing,
That would pretend to his love, yes, and some gentlemen
That would fain counsel him, and be of his kindred;
Rich men can want no heirs, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They do ill,
Indeed they do, to trouble him: very ill, sir,
But we shall take a care.

div.stage: Enter Diego (In a bed) Millanes, Arsenio, and parishioners.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Will ye come near, sir,
Pray ye bring him out; now ye may see in what state:
Give him fresh air. Bed thrust out.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am sorry, neighbour Diego,
To find ye in so weak a state.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ye are welcome,
But I am fleeting, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Methinks he looks well,
His colour fresh, and strong, his eyes are cheerful.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A glimmering before death, 'tis nothing else sir,
Do you see how he fumbles with the sheet? do ye note that

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: My learned sir pray ye sit: I am bold to send for ye,
To take a care of what I leave.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Do you hear that?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Play the knave finely.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: So I will, I warrant ye,
And carefully.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pray ye do not trouble him,
You see he's weak and has a wand'ring fancy.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: My honest neighbours, weep not, I must leave ye,
I cannot always bear ye company,
We must drop still, there is no remedy:
Pray ye master curate, will ye write my testament,
And write it largely it may be remembered
And be witness to my legacies good gentlemen;
Your worship I do make my full executor,
You are a man of wit and understanding:
Give me a cup of wine to raise my spirits,
For I speak low: I would before these neighbours
Have ye to swear (Sir) that you will see it executed,
And what I give, let equally be rendered
For my soul's health.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I vow it truly, neighbours,
Let not that trouble ye before all these,
Once more I give my oath.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Then set me higher,
And pray ye come near me all.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We are ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Now spur the ass, and get our friend time.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: First then,
After I have given my body to the worms
(For they must be served first, they are seldom cozened)

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Remember your parish, neighbour.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: You speak truly,
I do remember it, a lewd vile parish,
And pray it may be mended: to the poor of it,
(Which is to all the parish) I give nothing,
For nothing, unto nothing, is most natural,
Yet leave as much space, as will build an hospital,
Their children may pray for me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What do you give to it?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Set down two thousand ducats,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis a good gift,
And will be long remembered.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To your worship,
(Because you must take pains to see all finished)
I give two thousand more, it may be three, sir,
A poor gratuity for your painstaking.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: These are large sums;

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing to him that has 'em.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To my old master vicar, I give five hundred,
(Five hundred, and five hundred, are too few sir)
But there be more to serve.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This fellow coins sure.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Give me some more drink. Pray ye buy books, buy books,
You have a learned head, stuff it with libraries,
And understand 'em, when ye have done, 'tis justice,
Run not the parish mad with controversies,
Nor preach not abstinence to longing women,
'Twill budge the bottoms of their consciences:
I would give the church new organs, but I prophecy
The churchwardens would quickly pipe 'em out o'th' parish,
Two hundred ducats more to mend the chancel,
And to paint true orthography, as many,
They write sunt with a c, which is abominable,
Pray you set that down, to poor maiden's marriages.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I that's well thought of, what's your will in that point?
A meritorious thing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No end of this will?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I give per annum two hundred ells of lockram,
That there be no straight dealings in their linens,
But the sails cut according to their burdens;
To all bell-ringers, I bequeath new ropes,
And let them use 'em at their own discretions.

sp.speaker: Ars
sp.l: You may remember us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I do, good gentlemen,
And I bequeath ye both good careful surgeons
A legacy, you have need of, more than money,
I know you want good diets and good lotions,
And in your pleasures good take heed.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He raves now.
But 'twill be quickly off,

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I do bequeath ye
Commodities of pins: brown papers: pack-threads,
Roast pork and puddings: gingerbread, and jews-trumps,
Of penny pipes, and mouldy pepper: take 'em,
Take 'em even where you please, and be cozened with 'em,
I should bequeath ye executions also,
But those I'll leave to th'law.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Now he grows temperate.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You will give no more?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I am loath to give more from ye,
Because I know you will have a care to execute
Only, to pious uses, sir, a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If he be worth all these, I am made for ever,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I give to fatal dames, that spin men's threads out,
And poor distressed damsels, that are militant
As members of our own afflictions,
A hundred crowns to buy warm tubs to work in,
I give five hundred pounds to buy a churchyard,
A spacious Church-yard, to lay thieves and knaves in,
Rich men, and honest men, take all the room up.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Are ye not weary?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Never of well-doing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: These are mad legacies.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: They were got as madly;
My sheep, and oxen, and my movables,
My plate, and jewels, and five hundred acres;
I have no heirs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This cannot be, 'tis monstrous.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Three ships at sea too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You have made me full executor.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Full, full, and total, would I had more to give ye
But these may serve an honest mind.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye say true,
A very honest mind, and make it rich too;
Rich, wondrous rich, but where shall I raise these moneys,
About your house? I see no such great promises;
Where shall I find these sums?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Even where you please sir,
You are wise and provident and know business
E'en raise 'em where you shall think good, I am reasonable

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Think good? will that raise thousands?
What do you make me?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: You have sworn to see it done, that's all my comfort.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Where I please? this is packed sure to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Ye are just and honest, and I know you will do it,
E'en where you please, for you know where the wealth is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am abused, betrayed, I am laughed at, scorned,
Baffled, and bored, it seems.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: No, no, ye are fooled.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Most finely fooled, and handsomely, and neatly,
Such cunning masters must be fooled sometimes, sir,
And have their worships noses wiped, 'tis healthful,
We are but quit: you fool us of our moneys
In every cause, in every quiddit wipe us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha ha, some more drink, for my heart, gentlemen,
This merry lawyer — ha, ha, ha, ha this scholar —
I think this fit will cure me: this executor —
I shall laugh out my lungs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This is derision above sufferance, villainy
Plotted, and set against me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Faith 'tis knavery,
In troth I must confess, thou art fooled indeed, lawyer.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Did you think, had this man been rich —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis well, sir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He would have chosen such a wolf, a cancer,
A maggot-pate, to be his whole executor.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A lawyer, that entangles all men's honesties,
And lives like a spider in a cobweb lurking,
And catching at all flies, that pass his pitfalls?
Puts powder to all states, to make 'em caper?
Would he trust you?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Do you deserve? I find, gentlemen,
This cataplasm of a well cozened lawyer
Laid to my stomach lenifies my fever,
Methinks I could eat now and walk a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am ashamed to feel how flat I am cheated,
How grossly, and maliciously made a may-game,
A damned trick; my wife, my wife, some rascal:
My credit, and my wife, some lustful villain,
Some bawd, some rogue,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Some crafty fool has found ye:
This 'tis sir, to teach ye to be too busy,
To covet all the gains, and all the rumours
To have a stirring oar, in all men's actions.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We did this, but to vex your fine officiousness.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Good 'Yield ye and God thank ye: I am fooled, gentlemen;
The lawyer is an ass, I do confess it,
A weak dull shallow ass: good even to your worships:
Vicar, remember vicar, rascal remember,
Thou notable rich rascal.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I do remember, sir,
Pray ye stay a little, I have e'en two legacies
To make your mouth up, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Remember varlets,
Quake and remember, rogues; I have brine for your buttocks. Ex.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O how he frets, and fumes now like a dunghill.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: His gall contains fine stuff now to make poisons,
Rare damned stuff.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Let's after him, and still vex him,
And take my friend off: by this time he has prospered,
He cannot lose this dear time: 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Well Diego, thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Hast done it daintily.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And shalt be as well paid, boy —

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Go, let's crucify him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I have told ye all my story, and how desperately.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I do believe: let's walk on, time is precious,
Not to be spent in words, here no more wooing,
The open air's an enemy to lovers,Pewter ready for noise.
Do as I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I'll do any thing,
I am so overjoyed, I'll fly to serve ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Take your joy moderately, as it is ministered,
And as the cause invites: that man's a fool
That at the sight o'th' bond, dances and leaps,
Then is the true joy, when the money comes.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: You cannot now deny me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nay, you know not,
Women have crotchets, and strange fits.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hold ye to that and swear it confidently,
Than I shall make a scruple to deny ye:
Pray ye let's step in, and see a friend of mine,
The weather's sharp: we'll stay but half an hour,
We may be missed else: a private fine house 'tis, sir,
And we may find many good welcomes.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Do lady,
Do happy lady.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: All your mind's of doing,
You must be modester.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I will be any thing. —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Open the doors, and give me room to chafe in
Mine own room, and my liberty: why maid there,
Open, I say, and do not anger me,
I am subject to much fury: when ye dishclout?
When do ye come? Asleep , ye lazy hellhound?
Nothing intended, but your ease, and eating?
Nobody here? why wife, why wife? why jewel?
No tongue to answer me? Prithee (Good pupil)
Dispense a little with thy careful study,
And step to th' door, and let me in; nor he neither?
Ha! not at's study? nor asleep? nor nobody?
I'll make ye hear: the house of ignorance,
No sound inhabits here: I have a key yet
That commands all: I fear I am metamorphized.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He keeps his fury still, and may do mischief.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: He shall be hanged first, we'll be sticklers there, boys

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The hundred thousand dreams now, that possess him
Of jealousy, and of revenge, and frailty
Of drawing bills against us, and petitions.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And casting what his credit shall recover.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Let him cast till his maw come up, we care not.
You shall be still secured. A great noise within.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: We'll pay him home then;
Hark what a noise he keeps within?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Certain
Has set his chimneys of fire, or the devil roars there.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The codixes o'th' law are broke loose, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: He's fighting sure,

sp.speaker: Di
sp.l: I'll tell ye that immediately —Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Or doing some strange outrage on himself.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Hang him, he dares not be so valiant.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: There's nobody at home and he chafes like a lion,
And stinks withal. Noise still.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nobody ?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Not a creature,
Nothing within, but he and his law-tempest,
The ladies, dishes, kettles, how they fly all?
And how the glasses through the rooms?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: My friend sure
Has got her out and now he has made an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: See where the sea comes? how it foams, and brussels?
The great Leviathan o'th' law, how it tumbles?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Made every way an ass? abused on all sides?
And from all quarters, people come to laugh at me?
Rise like a comet, to be wondered at?
A horrid comet, for boys tongues, and ballads?
I will run from my wits.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Do, do, (Good lawyer)
And from thy money too, than thou wilt be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Here she comes home: now mark the salutations;
How like an ass my friend goes?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: She has pulled his ears down.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now, what sweet voyage? to what garden, lady?
Or to what cousin's house?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Is this my welcome?
I cannot go to church but thus I am scandaled,
Use no devotion for my soul, but gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: To church?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Yes, and ye keep sweet youths to wait upon me,
Sweet bred-up youths, to be a credit to me.
There's your delight again, pray take him to ye,
However comes near me more to debase me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How's this? how's this? good wife, how has he wronged ye?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I was fain to drive him like a sheep before me,
I blush to think how people fleer, and scorned me,
Others have handsome men, that know behaviour,
Place, and observance: this silly thing knows nothing,
Cannot tell ten; let every rascal justle me,
And still I pushed him on as he had been coming.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha! did ye push him on? is he so stupid?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: When others were attentive to the priest,
Good devout gentleman, then fell he fast
Fast, sound asleep: then first began the bagpipes
The several stops on's nose, made a rare music,
A rare and loud, and those played many an anthem
Put out of that, he fell straight into dreaming.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: As cunning, as she is sweet; I like this carriage.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What did he then?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why then he talked in his sleep too,
Nay I'll divulge your moral virtues (Sheeps-face)
And talked aloud, that every ear was fixed to him:
Did not I suffer (Do you think) in this time?
Talk of your bawling law, of appellations
Of declarations, and excommunications:
Warrants, and executions: and such devils
That drove all the gentlemen out o'th' church, by hurries
With execrable oaths, they would never come there again
Thus am I served, and maned.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I pray ye forgive me,
I must confess I am not fit to wait upon ye:
Alas, I was brought up —

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To be an ass,
A lawyer's ass, to carry books, and buckrams.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But what did you at church?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: At church, did ye ask her?
Do you hear gentlemen, do you mark that question?
Because you are half an heretic yourself, sir,
Would ye breed her too? this shall to the inquisition,
A pious gentlewoman, reproved for praying?
I'll see this filed, and you shall hear further, sir.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Ye have an ill heart.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It shall be found out gentlemen,
There be those youths will search it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: You are warm signior,
But a faggot will warm ye better: we are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Enough to hang him, do not doubt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Nay certain,
I do believe has rather no religion.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: That must be known too, because she goes to church, sir?
O monstrum inform ingens!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Let him go on, sir,
His wealth will build a nunnery, a fair one,
And this good lady, when he is hanged, and rotten,
May there be abbess.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are cozened, honest gentlemen,
I do not forbid the use, but the form, mark me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Form? what do ye make of form?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They will undo me,
Swear, as I oft have done, and so betray me;
I must make fair way, and hereafter, wife,
You are welcome home, and henceforth take your pleasure,
Go, when ye shall think fit, I will not hinder ye,
My eyes are open now, and I see my error,
My shame as great as that, but I must hide it.
The whole conveyance now I smell, but basta,
Another time must serve: you see us friends, now
Heartily friends and no more chiding (Gentlemen)
I have been too foolish, I confess, no more words,
No more (Sweet wife.)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know my easy nature

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go get ye in: you see she has been angry:
Forbear her sight a while and time will pacify.
And learn to be more bold.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I would I could,
I will do all I am able. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do Leandro,
We will not part, but friends of all hands.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Well said,
Now ye are reasonable, we can look on ye,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye have jerked me: but for all that I forgive ye
Forgive ye heartily, and do invite ye
Tomorrow to a breakfast, I make but seldom
But now we will be merry.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Now ye are friendly,
Your doggedness and niggardise flung from ye.
And now we will come to ye

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Give me your hands, all;
You shall be welcome heartily.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We will be,
For we'll eat hard

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The harder, the more welcome,
And till the morning farewell; I have business. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Farewell good bountiful Bartolus 'tis a brave wench
A sudden witty thief, and worth all service:
Go we'll all go, and crucify the lawyer,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'll clap four tire of teeth into my mouth more
But I will grind his substance.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Well Leandro,
Thou hast had a strange voyage, but I hope
Thou ridest now in safe harbour,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Let's go drink, friends,
And laugh aloud at all our merry may-games

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A match, a match 'twill whet our stomachs better.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Madam he's come. Chair and stools out.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis well how did he look,
When he knew from whom you were sent? was he not startled?
Or confident? or fearful?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: As appeared
Like one that knew his fortune at the worst,
And cared not what could follow.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis the better
Reach me a chair: so bring him in, be careful
That none disturb us: I will try his temper,
And if I find him apt for my employments,
I'll work him to my ends, if not I shall
Find other engines.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There's my lady,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Leave us

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: You sent for me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I did, and does the favour,
Your present state considered, and my power,
Deserve no greater ceremony?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Ceremony?
I use to pay that, where I do owe duty,
Not to my brother's wife: I cannot fawn,
If you expect it from me, you are cozened,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: He bears up still; I like it,
Pray you a word

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Yes: I will give you hearing
On equal terms, and sit by you as a friend,
But not stand as a suitor: now your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You are very bold.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: 'Tis fit: since you are proud
I was not made to feed that foolish humour,
With flattery and observance

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yet, with your favour,
A little form joined with respect to her,
That can add to your wants, or free you from 'em
(Nay raise you to a fate, beyond your hopes)A table ready covered with cloth napkins salt trenchers and bread.
Might well become your wisdom,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: It would rather
Write me a fool, should I but only think
That any good to me, could flow from you,
Whom for so many years: I have found and proved
My greatest enemy: I am still the same
My wants have not transformed me: I dare tell you,
To your new cerviz'd face, what I have spoken
Freely behind your back, what I think of you,
You are the proudest thing, and have the least,
Reason to be so, that I ever read of
In stature you are a giantess: and your tailor
Takes measure of you, with a Jacob's staff,
Or he can never reach you, this by the way
For your large size: now, in a word, or two
To treat of your complexion were decorum:
You are so far from fair, I doubt your mother
Was too familiar with the Moor, that served her,
Your limbs and features, I pass briefly over,
As things not worth description; and come roundly
To your soul, if you have any: for 'tis doubtful

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I laugh at this, proceed

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: This soul, I speak of
Or rather salt to keep this heap of flesh,
From being a walking stench, like a large inn,
Stands open for the entertainment of
All impious practises: but there's no corner
An honest thought can take up: and as it were not
Sufficient in yourself to comprehend
All wicked plots, you have taught the fool, my brother
By your contagion, almost to put off
The nature of the man, and turned him devil
Because he should be like you, and I hope
Will march to hell together: I have spoken,
And if the limming you, in your true colours
Can make the painter gracious, I stand ready
For my reward, or if my words distaste you
I weigh it not, for though your grooms were ready
To cut my throat for't, be assured I cannot
Use other language

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You think you have said now,
Like a brave fellow: in this woman's war
You ever have been trained: spoken big: but suffered
Like a tame ass; and when most spurred and galled
Were never master of the spleen or spirit,
That could raise up the anger of a man,
And force it into action,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Yes vile creature
Were't thou a subject worthy of my sword,
Or that thy death, this moment, could call home,
My banished hopes, thou now were't dead: dead (Woman)
But being as thou art, it is sufficient
I scorn thee, and contemn thee

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: This shows nobly:
I must confess it: I am taken with it
For had you kneeled, and whined and showed a base
And low dejected mind, I had despised you
This bravery (In your adverse fortune) conquers
And does command me, and upon the sudden
I feel a kind of pity, growing in me,
For your misfortunes, pity some says the parent,
Of future love, and I repent my part,
So far in what you have suffered, that I could,
(But you are cold) do something to repair
What your base brother (Such Iami I think him)
Hath brought to ruin

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Be not amazed,
Our injuries are equal in his bastard
You are familiar with what I groan for
And though the name of husband holds a tie
Beyond a brother, ay, a poor weak woman,
Am sensible, and tender of a wrong,
And to revenge it, would break through all lets,
That durst oppose me.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: By this kiss: start not: thus much, as a stranger
You may take from me; but, if you were pleased,
I should select you, as a bosom friend,
I would print 'em, thus, and thus,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Keep off.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Come near,
Near into the cabinet of my counsels:
Simplicity and patience dwell with fools,
And let them bear those burdens, which wise men
Boldly shake off; be mine and join with me,
And when that I have raised you to a fortune,
(Do not deny yourself the happy means)
You'll look on me, with more judicious eyes
And swear I am most fair,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: What would this woman?
The purpose of these words? speak not in riddles
And when I understand what you would counsel,
My answer shall be sudden,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Thus then Jami,
The objects of our fury, are the same,
For young Ascanio, whom you snake like huged
(Frozen with wants to death) in your warm bosom,
Lives to supplant you in your certain hopes,
And kills in me all comfort.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Now 'tis plain,
I apprehend you: and were he removed —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You, once again were the undoubted heir.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: 'Tis not to be denied; I was ice before,
But now ye have fired me, —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'll add fuel to it,
And by a nearer cut, do you but steer
As I direct you bring our bark into
The port of happiness,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: By Henriques death:
But you'll say he's your brother; in great fortunes
(Which are epitomes of states and kingdoms)Dishes covered with papers in each ready.
The politic brook no rivals.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Excellent.
For sure I think out of a scrupulous fear,
To feed in expectation when I may
(Dispensing but a little with my conscience)
Come into full possession, would not argue
One that desired to thrive,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now you speak like
A man that knows the world.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I needs must learn
That have so good a tutoress: and what think you,
(Don Henrique and Ascanio cut off)
That none may live, that shall desire to trace us
In our black paths, if that Octavio
His foster father 'And the sad Jacinta,
(Faith pity her, and free her from her sorrows)
Should fall companions with'em ? When we are red
With murder, let us often bathe in blood,
The colour will be scarlet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And that's glorious,
And will protect the fact

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Suppose this done:
(If undiscovered) we may get for money,
(As that you know buys any thing in Rome)
A dispensation

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And be married?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: True.
Or if it be known, truss up our gold and jewels,
And fly to some free state, and there with scorn —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Laugh at the laws of Spain.
'Twere admirable.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: We shall beget rare children. I am raped with
The mere imagination —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Shall it be done?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Shall? 'tis too tedious: furnish me with means
To hire the instruments, and to yourself,
Say it is done already: I will show you,
'Ere the sun set, how much you have wrought upon me,
Your province is only to use some means,
To send my brother, to the grove that's neighbour,
To the West port of th' city; leave the rest,
To my own practice; I have talked too long:
But now will do: this kiss, with my confession,
To work a fell revenge: a man's a fool,
If not instructed in a woman's school. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Bartolus algazeirs and a paratour. The table set out and stools.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are well enough disguised, furnish the table,
Make no show, what ye are, till I discover
Not a soul knows ye here: be quick and diligent,
These youths, I have invited to a breakfast,
But what the sauce will be, I am of opinion
I shall take off the edges of their appetites,
And grease their gums, for eating heartily;
This month or two they have played their prizes with me
And with their several flurts they have lighted dangerously
But sure I shall be quit: I hear 'em coming
Go off, and wait the bringing in your service,
And do it handsomely: you know where to have it
Wellcome i'faith,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: That's well said, honest lawyer,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Said like a neighbour

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wellcome all: all over
And let's be merry:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: To that end we came sir,
An hour of freedom's worth an age of jugglings,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I am come too sir, to specify my stomach
A poor retainer to your worship's bounty,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And thou shalt have it filled, my merry Diego,
My liberal, and my bonney bounteous Diego
Even filed till it groan again

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Let it have fair play,
And if it founder then —
I'll tell ye neighbours,
Though I were angry yesterday, with ye all,
And very angry for methought ye bobbed me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: No, no, by no means.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, when I considered
It was a jest, and carried off so quaintly
It made me merry: very merry, gentlemen,
I do confess I could not sleep to think on't
The mirth so tickled me, I could not slumber,

sp.speaker: Lop,
sp.l: Good mirth does work so: honest mirth,
Now, should we have meant in earnest —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You say true neighbour,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It might have bred such a distaste and sourness,
Such fond imaginations in your brains, sir
For things thrust home in earnest —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Very certain
But I know ye all for merry wags, and ere long
You shall know me too. in another fashion
Though you're pampered ye shall bear part oth' burden.
Come wife; come bid 'em welcome; come my jewel:
And pupil, you shall come too; ne'er hang backward,
Come, come the woman's pleased, her anger's over,
Come, be not bashful,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What does he prepare here?
Sure there's no meat ith' house at least none dressed,
Does he mean to mock 'em? or some new bred crotchet
Come o'er his brains; I do not like his kindness?
But silence best becomes me: if he mean foul play
Sure they are enough to right themselves and let 'em,
I'll sit by, so they beat him not to powder,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Bring in the meat there, ha? Sit down dear neighbour
A little meat needs little compliment,
Sit down I say:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What do you mean by this sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Convey away their weapons handsomely,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know there's none ith' house to answer ye,
But the poor girl; you know there's no meat neither

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace and be quiet; I shall make you smoke else
There's men and meat enough, set it down formally

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I fear some lewd trick, yet I dare not speak on't

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have no dainties for ye gentlemen,
Nor ●odes of meat, to make the room smell of 'em
Only a dish to every man I have dedicated,
And if I have pleased his appetite,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O, a capon,
A bird of grace, and be thy will, I honour it

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: For me some forty pound of lovely beef,
Placed in a Mediterranean sea of brewisse

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fall to, fall to that we may drink and laugh after
Wait diligently knaves,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What rare bits this?
An execution, bless me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay take it to ye
There's no avoiding it 'tis somewhat tough sir,
But a good stomach will endure it easily
The sum is, but a thousand ducats sir,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: A capias from my surgeon, and my silk man,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your careful makers, but they have marred your diet
Stir not, your swords are gone: there's no avoiding me
And these are Algazeir's, do you hear that passing bell?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A strong citation, bless me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Out with your beads, curate,
The devils in your dish: bell, book, and candle,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A warrant to appear before the judges?
I must needs rise, and turn to'th wall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye need not,
Your fear I hope will make ye find your breeches,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are betrayed

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Invited, do not wrong me,
Fall to, good guests, you have diligent men about ye,
Ye shall want nothing, that may persecute ye
These will not see ye start; have I now found ye
Have I requited ye? You fooled the lawyer,
And thought it meritorious, to abuse him,
A thick ram headed knave: you rid, you spurred him,
And glorified your wits, the more ye wronged him;
Within this hour, ye shall have all your creditors,
A second dish of new debts, come upon ye,
And new invitements to the whip (Don Diego)
And excommunications for the learned curate,
A masque of all your furies shall dance to ye,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: You dare not use us thus?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You shall be bobbed (Gentlemen)
Stir, and as I have a life, ye go to prison
To prison, without pity instantly
Before ye speak another word to prison.
I have a better guard, without, that waits;
Do you see this man, don curate? 'tis a paratour
That comes to tell ye a delightful story.
Of an old whore, ye have and then to teach ye
What is the penalty; laugh at me now sir,
What legacy would ye bequeath me now,
(And pay it on the nail?) to fly my fury?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O gentle sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Dost thou hope I will be gentle,
Thou foolish unconsiderate curate?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Let me go sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll see thee hang first.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And as I am a true vicar,
Hark in your ear, hark softly —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, no bribery.
I'll have my swinge upon thee; sirrah? Rascal?
You lenten chaps, you that lay sick, and mocked me,
Mocked me, abominably; abused me lewdly
I'll make thee sick at heart, before I leave thee,
And groan, and die indeed, and be worth nothing
Not worth a blessing, nor a bell to knell for thee,
A sheet to cover thee, but that thou stealest,
Stealest from the merchant, and the ring he was buried with
Stealest from his grave, do you smell me now?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No psalm of mercy shall hold me from hanging thee
How do ye like your breakfast? 'tis but short, gentlemen
But sweet and healthful; your punishment, and yours, sir
For some near reasons, that concerns my credit,
I will take to myself.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do sir, and spare not
I have been too good a wife, and too obedient,
But since ye dare provoke me to be foolish —

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: She has, yes, and too worthy of your usage,
Before the world, I justify her goodness,
And turn that man, that dares but taint her virtues,
To my sword's point; that lying man, that base man,
Turn him, but face to face, that I may know him

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What have I here?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: A gentleman, a free man,
One that made trial of this lady's constancy,
And found it strong as fate; leave off your fooling,
For if you follow this course, you will be chronicled
For a devil, whilst a saint she is mentioned,
You know my name indeed; I am now no lawyer.
Some comfort now, I hope, or else would I were hanged up

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: And yet the judge, he makes me sweat.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What news now?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I will justify upon my life, and credit
What you have heard, for truth, and will make proof of

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: I will be ready at the appointed hour there,
And so I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Stay I beseech your worship,
And do but hear me,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Good sir, intend this business,
And let this bawling fool; no more words lawyer,
And no more angers, for I guess your reasons,
This gentleman, I'll justify in all places,
And that fair lady's worth; let who dare cross it,
The plot was cast by me, to make thee jealous,
But not to wrong your wife, she is fair and virtuous,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Take us to mercy too, we beseech your honour,
We shall be justified the way of all flesh else,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: No more talk, nor no more dissension lawyer,
I know your anger, 'tis a vain and slight one,
For if you do; I'll lay your whole life open
A life that all the world shall I'll bring witness,
And rip before a judge the ulcerous villainies
You know I know ye, and I can bring witness.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay good sir, noble sir.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Be at peace then presently,
Immediately take honest and fair truce
With your good wife, and shake hands with that gentleman;
Has honoured ye too much, and do it cheerfully,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Take us along, for heaven's sake too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am friends,
There is no remedy, I must put up all,
And like my neighbours rub it out by'th shoulders,
And perfect friends; Leandro now I thank ye,
And there's my hand, I have no more grudge to ye,
But I am too mean henceforward for your company,

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I shall not trouble ye,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: We will be friends too:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Nay lawyer, you shall not fright us farther,
For all your devils we will bolt,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I grant ye.
The gentleman's your bail and thank his coming,
Did not he know me too well, you should smart for't;
Go all in peace, but when ye fool next, gentlemen,
Come not to me to breakfast.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'll be baked first.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And pray ye remember, when ye are bold and merry,
The lawyer's banquet, and the sauce he gave ye,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Come: go along; I have employment for ye,
Employment for your lewd brains too, to cool ye.
For all, for every one.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are all your servants.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: All, all for any thing, from this day forward,
I'll hate all breakfasts, and depend on dinners

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I am glad you come off fair

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: The fair has blessed me.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This is the place, but why we are appointed
By don Jami to stay here, is a depth
I cannot sound,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Believe't he is too noble,
To purpose any thing but for our good
Had I assurance of a thousand lives,
And with them perpetuity of pleasure,
And should lose all, if he proved only false,
Yet I durst run the hazard,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis our comfort,
We cannot be more wretched than we are,
And death concludes all misery,

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Undiscovered
We must attend him

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Our stay is not long
With him don Henrique?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Now I fear;
Be silent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why dost thou follow me?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: To save your life,
A plot is laid for't, all my wrongs forgotten,
I have a brother's love,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: But thy false self,
I fear no enemy.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: You have no friend,
But what breathes in me: if you move a step
Beyond this ground you tread on: you are lost.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis by thy practice then: I am sent hither
To meet her, that prefers my life, and safety
Before her own.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: That you should be abused thus
With weak credulity: she for whose sake,
You have forgotten we had one noble father,
Or that one mother bore us, for whose love,
You break a contract, to which heaven was witness,
To satisfy whose pride, and wilful humour,
You have exposed a sweet, and hopeful son,
To all the miseries, that want can bring him,
And such a son, though you are most obdurate,
To give whom entertainment savages
Would quit their caves themselves, to keep him from
Bleak cold, and hunger: this dissembling woman,
This idol, whom you worship: all your love
And service trod under her feet, designs you
To fill a grave or dead, to lie a prey,
For wolves, and vultures.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis false; I defy thee,
And stand upon my guard

div.stage: Enter Leandro Millanes, Arsenio, Bart. Lopez, deigo, Octavio Jacinta Ascanio and servants.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis weak:
Come on, since you will teach me to be cruel,
By having no faith, in me, take your fortune,
Bring the rest forth, and bind them fast.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: In what have we offended?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I am deaf,
And following my will, I do not stand
Accountable to reason: see her ring
(The first pledge of your love, and service to her)
Delivered as a warrant for your death:
These bags of gold you gave up to her trust,
(The use of which, you did deny yourself)
Bestowed on me, and with a prodigal hand,
Whom she picked forth to be the architect
Of her most bloody building; and to fee
These instruments, to bring materials
To raise it up, she bade me spare no cost,
And (As a surplusage) offered herself
To be at my devotion.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: O accursed!

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: But be incredulous still; think this my plot;
Fashion excuses to yourself, and swear
That she is innocent, that she dotes on ye;
Believe this, as a fearful dream, and that
You I'll not at my mercy, which in this
I will show only: she herself shall give
The dreadful sentence, to remove all scruple
Who 'tis that sends you to the other world.
Appears my Violante? speak (My dearest)
Does not the object please you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: More than if
All treasure that's above the earth, with that,
That lies concealed in both the Indian mines,
Were laid down at my feet: oh bold Jamy
Thou only canst deserve me.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I am forward,
And (As you easily may perceive,) I sleep not
On your commands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But yet they live: I looked
To find them dead.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: That was deferred, that you
Might triumph in their misery, and have the power
To say they are not,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Twas well thought upon:
This kiss, and all the pleasures of my bed
This night, shall thank thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Monster!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You sir, that
Would have me mother bastards, being unable
To honour me with one child of mine own,
That underneath my roof, kept your cast-strumpet,
And out of my revenues, would maintain
Her riotous issue: now you find what 'tis
To tempt a woman: with as little feeling
As I turn off a slave, that is unfit
To do me service; or a horse, or dog
That have outlived their use, I shake thee off,
To make thy peace with heaven.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I do deserve this,
And never truly felt before, what sorrow
Attends on wilful dotage.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: For you, mistress,
That had the pleasure of his youth before me,
And triumphed in the fruit, that you had by him,
But that I think, to have the bastard strangled
Before thy face, and thou with speed to follow
The way he leads thee, is sufficient torture,
I would cut off thy nose, put out thine eyes,
And set my foot on these bewitching lips,
That had the start of mine: but as thou art,
Go to the grave unpitied.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Who would believe
Such rage could be in woman?

sp.speaker: Viol,
sp.l: For this fellow,
He is not worth my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Let him live then,
Since you esteem him innocent.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: No, Jamy,
He shall make up the mess: now strike together
And let them fall so.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Unheard of cruelty
I can endure no longer: seize on her.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Am I betrayed?
Is this thy faith, Jamy?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Could your desires
Challenge performance of a deed so horrid?
Or, though that you had sold yourself to hell,
I should make up the bargain? Live (Dear brother)
Live long, and happy: I forgive you freely;
To have done you this service, is to me
A fair inheritance: and howe'er harsh language
(Called on, by your rough usage) passed my lips,
In my heart, I ever loved you: all my labours
Were but to show, how much your love was cozened,
When it beheld itself in this false glass,
That did abuse you; and I am so far
From envying young Ascanio his good fortune,
That if your state were mine, I would adopt him.
These are the murderers my noble friends,
Which (To make trial of her bloody purpose)
I won, to come disguised thus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I am too full
Of grief, and shame to speak: but what I'll do,
Shall to the world proclaim my penitence;
And howsoever I have lived, I'll die
A much changed man.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Were it but possible
You could make satisfaction to this woman,
Our joys were perfect.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: That's my only comfort,
That it is in my power: I never was married
To this bad woman, though I doted on her,
But daily did defer it still expecting
When grief would kill Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: All is come out,
And finds a fair success: take her don Henrique,
And once again embrace your son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Most gladly.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Your brother hath deserved well.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And shall share
The moiety of my state,

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: I have heard, advocate,
What an ill instrument you have been to him,
From this time strengthen him, with honest counsels,
As you'll deserve my pardon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll change my copy:
But I am punished, for I fear I have had
A smart blow, though unseen.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Curate, and sexton,
I have heard of you too, let me hear no more,
And what's past, is forgotten; for this woman,
Though her intent were bloody, yet our law
Calls it not death: yet that her punishment
May deter others from such bad attempts,
The dowry she brought with her shall be employed
To build a nunnery, where she shall spend
The remnant of her life.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Since I have missed my ends,
I scorn what can fall on me.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: The strict discipline
Of the church, will teach you better thoughts. And signiors.
You that are bachelors, if you ever marry,
In Bartolus, you may behold the issue
Of covetousness, and jealousy; and of dotage,
And falsehood in don Henrique keep a mean then;
For be assured that weak man meets all ill,
That gives himself up to a woman's will. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: To tell ye (Gentlemen,) we have a play,
A new one too, and that 'tis launched today,
The name ye know, that's nothing to my story;
To tell ye, 'tis familiar, void of glory;
Of state, of bitterness: of wit you'll say,
For that is now held wit, that tends that way,
Which we avoid: to tell ye to 'tis merry,
And meant to make ye pleasant, and not weary:
The stream that guides ye, easy to attend:
To tell ye that 'tis good, is to no end,
If you believe not. Nay, to go thus far,
To swear it, if you swear against, is war
To assure you any thing, unless you see,
And so conceive, is vanity in me;
Therefore I leave it to itself, and pray
Like a good bark, it may work out today,
And stem all doubts; 'twas built for such a proof,
And we hope highly: if she lie aloof
For her own vantage, to give wind at will,
Why let her work, only be you but still,
And sweet opinioned, and we are bound to say,
You are worthy judges, and you crown the play.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: The play is done, yet our suit never ends,
Still when you part, you would still part our friends,
Our noblest friends; if ought have fallen amiss,
Oh let it be sufficient, that it is,
And you have pardoned it. In buildings great
All the whole body, cannot be so neat,
But something may be mended; those are fair,
And worthy love, that may destroy, but spare.

A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length.
